English: Now if, instead of doing this, we grieve the Holy Spirit,—by going against our consciences,—by refusing to obey the precepts of Christ, when we know them,—by yielding to the temptations of the devil, without asking God’s help, without which we know we cannot resist the powerful spirit;—if we continue to do so, though the Spirit of God shews us the great danger we are in, then we grieve the Holy Ghost, by which we were sanctified, and he will leave us to ourselves, and we shall certainly be ruined.

Manx: Er-jerrey; (son ooilley cooney Spyrryd Casheric Yee) ta ymmodee ayn, ta er ghoail seose kiarailyn mie dy hirveish Jee, as ny-yeih cha vel cheet lhieu son laccal tannaghtyn ayndoo gys jerrey ny mea:—son edyr t’ad mee-hreishteil dy jig lhieu, trooid ennaghtyn jeh nyn annoonid hene,—er-nonney t’ad meerioosagh ayns jannoo yn ymmyd share oddys ad jeh ny saasyn dy ghrayse ta Jee son y traa shen er choyrt daue;—edyr yn derrey yeh na’n jeh elley jeu shoh vees ayns dy chooilley hickyrys nyn doyrt-mouys.
English: Lastly, (notwithstanding the assistance of God’s Holy Spirit) there are many, who have taken up good resolutions of serving God, and yet miscarry for want of continuing in them unto their lives end:—for either they despair of succeeding, through a sense of their own weakness, or they neglect to make use of and to improve the means of grace, which for the present God has given them;—either of which will most certainly be their ruin.

Manx: Agh, ayns ynnyd ve ass cree dy jig lhieu, dy goghe sleih huc hene, dy vel eshyn ta ayninyn, (ta shen, yn Spyrryd Noo) ny s’pooaral na eshyn ta ayns y theihl, (ta shen, yn Jouyl.) Dy jinnagh sleih agh cooinaghtyn er pooar yn Spyrryd Noo, myr t’yh er ny hoilshaghey dooin ayns ny Scriptyryn Catheric, liorish haink deiney gyn ynsagh chelleeragh dy ve nyn vir-ynsee da feallagh elley;—yn Spyrryd Noo niartaghey lhieu dy loayrt glaaraghyn nagh row ad roie toiggal,—dy obbraghey mirrillyn, dy chonfirmal yn ynsagh oc,—as dy choyrt ard-shickyrys da’n seihl nagh nee Spyrryd dy haghrynys na dy volteyrys va ayndoo.
English: But if, instead of despairing of success, people would consider, that greater is he that is in us, (that is, the Holy Ghost) than he that is in the world, (that is, the Devil.) If people would but call to mind the power of the Holy Ghost, as it is delivered to us in the Holy Scriptures, by whom ignorant men became of a sudden teachers of others;—the Holy Ghost enabling them to speak unknown languages,—to work miracles, to confirm their doctrines, and to convince the world that they were not possessed with a Spirit of error and delusion.

Manx: Dy jinnagh sleih agh tastey y ghoail cre’n caghlaa ta jeant orroosyn, quoi, veih ard-pheccee [411] ta er jeet dy ve nyn arryssee firrinagh; quoi, veih ve dy ard-miandagh er pecca, ta er jeet dy ve cha miandagh cheddin er casherickys,—dy ve lesh smooinaghtyn cleer controllee mychione nyn ymmyrkey-bea roie,—nagh vel nish jeeaghyn er pecca myr red gyn loght, dy eiyrt da na gyn, agh myr dy jarroo t’yh, dy ve er ny hea veih ny s’leaie na’n baase hene. Ayns fockle, dy vel nyn slane cree as spyrryd er ve caghlait na jeant noa, ayns wheesh as dy vel ny Scriptyryn genmys shoh bea noa, as ve er ny ruggey-reesht.
English: If men would observe what a change is made upon those who from great sinners have become true penitents; that, from having been strongly inclined to sin, they are become as much inclined to holiness,—to have quite different thoughts of their former way of living,—not now to look upon sin as a harmless, indifferent thing, but, as indeed it is, to be avoided rather than death itself. In a word, that their whole man has been changed or made new, in so much as the Scriptures call this a new birth, and being born again.

Manx: Quoi-erbee ta smooinaghtyn dy sheelt er ny reddyn shoh nee eh goail-rish, nagh vel nhee erbee neu-phossibyl da Jee,—as ga dy vel nyn beccaghyn whilleen shen nagh vod mayd coontey seose ad,—ga nagh vel pooar erbee ain ji’n-hene dy chooney lhien hene;—ny-yeih my nee mayd dy jeean shirrey gys Jee son cooney, as goail greme er ny saaseyn chebbit dooin, shickyr t’yh dy bee mayd sauchey, my nee mayd ymmyd jeh’n towse shen dy ghrayse ta Jee dy choyrt dooin;—son ta shoh ny rule er ny choyrt dooin liorish nyn Saualtagh Bannee:— “Quoi-erbee ta echey, dasyn vees er ny choyrt, as bee towse s’feoiltey echey; agh quoi-erbee nagh vel echey, veihsyn vees er ny ghoail ersooyl eer shen hene er-lesh dy vel echey.”
English: Whoever thinks seriously of these things will conclude, that there is nothing impossible with God,—and that though our sins are so many that we cannot recount them, though we have no power of ourselves to help ourselves;—yet if we earnestly seek to God for help, and lay hold of the means offered to us, it is certain we shall be safe, provided we use that measure of grace which God gives us;— for this is a rule given us by our Blessed Saviour: “To him that hath shall be given, and he shall have abundantly; but from him that hath not, shall be taken away even that which he seemeth to have.”

Manx: Quoi-erbee ta echey, (ta shen, ta er n’yannoo ymmyd vie jeh’n ghrayse ta Jee er choyrt [412] da) dasyn ver eh ny smoo dy ghrayse: Agh eshyn ta jannoo meerioose er ny saaseyn dy ghrayse, veihsyn vees er ny ghoail ersooyl eer shen hene va er ny choyrt da roie.
English: To him that hath, (that is, that hath made use of the grace which God hath given him) to him God will give more grace: But he that neglects the means of grace, from him shall be taken away even what before he had given him.

Manx: Cha vel sleih goail huc-hene cre’n red danjereagh t’yh dy chur shaghey smooinaghtyn mie,—dy yannoo meerioose er coyrle vie nyn gaarjyn,—dy chur slheh er ny caaghyn dy gheddyn toiggal jeh nyn gurrym. Dy goghe ad agh huc-hene, dy vel ad shoh ooilley nyn saaseyn dy ghrayse,—dy vel ad dy jarroo obbyr yn Spyrryd Noo,—cha jinnagh ad soiaghey cha eddrym jeu, agh veagh dy feer aggle orroo dy obbal ny towseyn sloo dy ghrayse ta foardrit daue cour nyn jyndaa as saualtys.
English: People do not consider how dangerous a thing it is to put by good thoughts,—to neglect the good advice of their friends,—to lose opportunities of knowing their duty. If they would but consider, that all these are means of grace, that they are indeed the work of the Holy Ghost,—they would not so easily despise them, [461] but would really be afraid of rejecting the least degrees of grace afforded them for their conversion and salvation.

Manx: Ren ny Phariseeyn [Luke vii. 30.] soiaghey beg jeh coyrle Yee,—e chiarail ghraysoil huc;—hoie ad beg jeh coyrle Yee ayns gobbal bashtey Ean; as jeeagh-jee cre b’erree da nyn soiaghey-beg jeh ny foayryn slooey shoh: Ren ad lurg shen soiaghey beg jeh Mac Yee hene, as e ynsaghey, ga dy row ad er nyn gonfirmal liorish mirrillyn.
English: The Pharisees [Luke vii. 30.] rejected the counsel of God,—his gracious design towards them;—they rejected the counsel of God in refusing the baptism of John; and look what followed their despising these lesser favours: They afterwards rejected the Son of God himself, and his doctrine, though approved and confirmed by miracles.

Manx: Yn Spyrryd cheddin ta er vockley magh, nagh jean eh brishey yn chuirtlagh vroojit, na cur ass yn byte giare-cheauit,—dy niartee eh lesh yn eer toshiaght dy chraueeaght, ta’n Spyrryd cheddin er loayrt ny goan atchimagh shoh myrgeddin: “Er-y-fa dy ren mish geamagh, as ren shiuish gobbal, dy [413] ren mee sheeyney magh my laue, as cha dug dooinney erbee geill da; neem’s myrgeddin garaghtee ec ny seaghyn eu, as craid tra hig yn aggle erriu.”—Red cha danjereagh shen t’yh dy hassoo noi na dy yannoo meerioose er Spyrryd Yee, as laa yn ghrayse!
English: The same Spirit, which has declared , that he will not break a bruised reed, nor quench the smoking flax,—that he will encourage the very beginnings of piety,—the same Spirit has also said these terrible words: “Because I called and ye refused, I stretched out my hand, and no man regarded; I will also laugh at your calamity, and mock when your fear cometh.”— So dangerous a thing it is to resist or to neglect the Spirit of God , and the day of grace!

Manx: Lhig dooin ooilley shoh y chur dy cheilley, as gys cree neesht.—
English: Let us lay all this together, and to heart too.—

Manx: Ta shin liorish dooghys ruggit ayns pecca, ayn beign dooin ve, bio as marroo, fegooish cooney as myghin Yee. Ta shin liorish bashtey jeant nyn gloan dy ghrayse as foayr: Da ooilley nyn lheid, ta’n Spyrryd Casheric er ny choyrt,―dy hoilshaghey nyn aignaghyn lesh firrinys y taualtys, dy leeideil ad ayns raaidyn chraueeaght as chasherickys,—dy choadey ad noi nyn noidyn anmey,—dy gherjaghey ad fo dy chooilley heaghyn,—as dy chur lesh ad dy sauchey gys niau.
English: We are by nature born in sin, in which we should live and die, without God’s help and mercy. We are by baptism made the children of grace and favour: To all that are so, the Holy Spirit is given, to enlighten their minds with saving truth,—to lead them in the ways of virtue and holiness,—to protect them against their spiritual enemies,—to comfort them under all adversities, and to bring them safe to Heaven.

Manx: Cour ny kiarailyn mooarey shoh, ta’n Spyrryd Noo er choyrt rule daue dy immeeaght liorish, ta shen, ny Scriptyryn Casheric,—Goo Yee. As dy vod ad treishteil gys y rule shen, t’eh er chonfirmal yh liorish ymmodee mirrillyn mooarey.
English: In order to these great ends, the Holy Ghost has given them a rule to walk by, namely, THE HOLY SCRIPTURES,—THE WORD OF GOD. And that they may trust to that rule, he has confirmed it by many great miracles.

Manx: T’eh myrgeddin er phointeil lheid yn Ordyr shen dy gheiney, quoi, fo yn penaltee s’geyrey ta dy jeidjagh dy phreacheil yn Goo shoh da e phobble, as t’eh er n’ghialdyn [414] dy vannaghey yn laboragh oc. Dy ghreinnaghey deiney dy eaishtagh roo, ta pooar er ny choyrt daue liorish yn Spyrryd Noo dy ghialdyn da ooilley nyn lheid as ver biallys da’n Ghoo shen, bannaghtyn yn vea shoh as jeh shen ta ry-heet.
English: He has also appointed a certain Order of Men, who, under the severest penalties, are faithfully to preach this Word unto his people, and he has promised to bless their labours. To encourage men to give ear to them, they are by the Holy Ghost impowered to promise all such as shall obey that Word, the blessings of this life and of that which is to come.—

Manx: As dy vod aggle ve er sleih dy yannoo meerioose er ny chebbyn graysoil shoh, t’yh pointit dauesyn dy hoiaghey roish yn pobble yn danjere atchimagh ta liorish jannoo shen, as dy vel yh red agglagh da peccagh dy huittym ayns laueyn y Jee Bio, ta abyl chamma annym as callin y stroie ayns niurin.
English: And, that men may be afraid to neglect these gracious offers, they are directed to set before the people the terrible danger of doing so, and that it is a dreadful thing for a sinner to fall into the hands of the Living GOD, who can destroy both body and soul in hell.

Manx: Ooilley nyn lheid as ta goail ny reddyn shoh gys cree, as ta aignagh dy hirveish Jee, as dy hauail nyn anmeenyn, ta’n Spyrryd Noo dy kinjagh aarloo dy chooney lhieu,—Liorish coyrt ayns nyn aignaghyn yeearreeyn mie,—liorish niartaghey ad dy yannoo shen ny ta eshyn er choyrt cree daue huggey,—liorish coyrt caaghyn daue dy ynsaghey as dy yannoo nyn gurrym,—liorish cooney lhieu tra t’ad miolit gys pecca,—as liorish troggal as gerjaghey ny creeaghyn oc, erreish daue ve er gheddyn barriaght er miolaghyn,—veih traa gy traa bishaghey e oayryn orroo, rere myr t’ad jannoo ymmyd vie jeu, derrey hig ad gys Flaunys, tra nagh bee arragh dy ghanjere.
English: All such as lay these things to heart, and are desirous of serving God, and of saving their souls, the Holy Ghost is ever ready to assist them,—By putting into their minds good desires, by enabling them to do what he has made them willing to do,—by giving them opportunities of learning and performing their duty,—by succouring them when they are tempted to sin,—and by encouraging and chearing their hearts, when they have overcome temptations,—from time to time increasing his favours as they make good use of them, until they come to Heaven, when all danger shall be over.

Manx: Er y cheu elley; ooilley nyn lheid as ta er ve er nyn gasherickey gys Jee ayns bashtey, [415] as tra t’ad er jeet gys tushtey, nagh vel dy dowin smooinaghtyn cre t’yh dy ve ny Chreestee; as nagh vel goail seose as lhiantyn rish ny saaseyn dy ghrayse ta foardrit daue; ec lheid ny persoonyn cha vel aght erbee er yn ooir dy haghney danjereyn seihl peccoil, miolaghyn spyrryd pooaral as olk, na treihyssyn y theihl ta ry-heet.
English: On the other hand; all such as have been dedicated to God in baptism , and, when they come to years of discretion , do not seriously think of what it is to be a Christian; or do not embrace and close with the means of grace afforded them; such persons have no possible way of escaping the dangers of a sinful world, the temptations of a powerful evil spirit, or the miseries of a future life.

Manx: Shen-y-fa, imree yh da dy chooilley ghooinney ta treishteil dy ve er ny hauail, (as quoi eh nagh vel?) t’yh lhie er dy chooilley ghooinney dy ghoail huggey hene, cre t’eh dy yannoo, tra t’eh soiaghey beg jeh na shassoo noi yn Spyrryd Noo geamagh er gys arrys as noa-id bea: Dy vel eh goail eh-hene ersooyl veih coadey Yee, as coyrt eh-hene ayns shirveish y Jouill;—nagh vod eh chyndaa tra saillish hene gys shirveish Yee, ny smoo na oddys eh goll gys niau fegooish kied Yee;—nagh vel fys ec y dooinney s’creeney c’raad nee eh sthappal, cre nee eh y yannoo, keayrt dy vel eh ventreil dy aagail ny raaidyn dy chredjue, as ny saaseyn dy ghrayse foardrit da ayns Agglish Yee.
English: Therefore, it behoves every man who hopes to be saved, (and who is there that does not?) it concerns every man to consider, what it is he is a doing, when he neglects or resists the Holy Ghost calling him to repentance and newness of life: That he is taking himself from under God’s protection, and putting himself into the service of the Devil;—that he cannot go back when he pleases into the service of God, no more than he can go to Heaven without the leave of God;—that the wisest man cannot tell where he shall stop, what he shall do, when once he ventures [462] to leave the ways of religion, and the means of grace afforded him in the Church of God.

Manx: As nagh lhig dooinney erbee gra nagh vel grayse as niart er ny choyrt da dy yannoo ny ta Jee jerkal rish voish; son cha vel Jee jerkal rish ny smoo na ymmyd onneragh y yannoo jeh’n towse shen dy ghrayse t’eh hanna er stowal er y dooinney.
English: And let no man say that he wants grace and strength to do what God expects from him; for God expects no more than an honest use of that measure of grace which he has already bestowed upon a man.

Manx: [416]   Cha vel yh er ny yerkal rish ayns unnane noa chyndait gys Jee, dy beagh eh slane ynric,—nagh jinnagh eh dy bragh tuittym gys raaidyn peccoil;—agh shoh ta er ny yerkal rish voish, dy jean eh chea (wheesh as ta pooar da) veih dy chooilley chleayn as miolagh gys pecca,—dy jean eh dy jeean padjer y ghoail son grayse as sheshaght y Spyrryd Noo dy ve marish,—traa erbee dy vel eh tuittym dy jean eh dy tappee chyndaa reesht gys Jee liorish arrys, as jannoo gialdynyn noa dy viallys. As quoi-erbee ta jannoo shoh veih grunt y chree, t’eh ayns raad y taualtys, as fo leeideilys Spyrryd Yee.
English: It is not expected from one newly converted, that he should be perfect,—that he should never fall into sinful courses;—but this is expected from him, that he should avoid all occasions (as much as possible) and temptations to sin,—that he should earnestly pray for grace and the fellowship of the Holy Ghost,—that whenever he falls he should speedily return to God by repentance, and make new resolutions of obedience. And whoever does this in good earnest, is in the way of salvation, and under the conduct of the Spirit of God.

Manx: Veih shoh foddee mayd toiggal, (as dy der Jee da ooilley ta’n chooish bentyn daue dy ghoail baght jeh, as dy ghoail yh gys cree) dy vod dy chooilley pheiagh ta dy mennic tuittym gys ny peccaghyn cheddin, as nagh vel streeu gys rere e phooar nyn oi, nagh vel chea veih miolagh,—nagh vel guee gys Jee son cooney—-dy vod lheid ny persoonyn shoh dy cooie goail huc hene nagh vel ad ayns raad y taualtys.
English: From whence we may conclude, (and I pray God all that are concerned may take notice, and lay it to heart) that every person who often falls into the same sins, and does not strive against them,—avoid temptation,—pray to God for help;—that such persons may justly apprehend that they are not in the way of salvation.

Manx: Dy choyrt jerrey er y slane chooish:—Ayns shoh ta dy chooilley ghreinnagh dooie ain oddys nyn greeaghyn y hirrey dy hyndaa gys Jee. Nee eh leih dooin ooilley ny t’er gholl shaghey;—nee eh niartaghey shin son y traa ta ry-heet;—nee eh cooney lhien tra ta shin tuittym;—as nee eh shin maynrey [417] tra yiow mayd baase. Cre’n-fa eisht yinnagh shin shaghey nyn arrys? Nee son nagh vel shin dy bragh kiarail dy ve sleih noa? O, cha nee; cha lhoys da’n peccagh s’daaney ny mast’ ain kiarail gyn dy bragh dy lhiassaghey e vea.
English: To conclude the whole:—Here is all the encouragement our hearts can desire to turn to God. He will forgive us what is past;—he will enable us for the time to come;—he will help us when we fall;—and he will make us happy when we die. Why, then, should we put off our repentance? Is it because we purpose never to become new men? O, no; the hardiest sinner amongst us dare not resolve never to amend.

Manx: Agh eisht lhig dooin cooinaghtyn, nagh nee tra sailli’n hene, agh tra s’cooidsave lesh yn Spyrryd Noo, dy jean mayd goail arrys as chyndaa gys Jee; as my ta’n Spyrryd Noo doostey aynin yeearree dy yannoo shen, as ta shinyn cur shaghey yn yeearree na yn aigney shen, my ta shin jannoo shoh dy mennic, ta lane oyr ain dy ve ayns aggle dy vaag eh shin dooin hene, as eisht bee yh neu-phossibyl dooin dy bragh dy ghoail arrys.
English: But then let us remember, that it is not when we please, but when the Holy Ghost pleases, that we shall repent and turn to God; and if the Holy Ghost stirs in us a desire of doing so, and we neglect that desire or inclination, if we do this often, we have much reason to fear he will leave us to ourselves, and then it will be impossible for us ever to repent.

Manx: Shen-y-fa, my ta veg euish, ta eu ennaghtyn dy vel shiu gys y traa shoh er leeideil bea almoragh, neu-chreestee;—my ta aggle erriu roish yn eiyrtys, as bwishal dy row shiu er hroggal erriu ny s’leaie;—my ta slane toiggal eu dy vel briwnyssyn Yee noi peccee agglagh-atchimagh as shickyr,—as my ta shiu dy jeean wishal dy row shiu ayns stayd by-hauchey;—eisht toig-jee, myr ta ny smooinaghtyn shoh leeideil gys arrys, dy vel ad veih Spyrryd mie Yee;—nagh vel veg jeh e ghleayshagh er y chree ayns fardail, agh tra ta sleih dy roonagh shassoo nyn ’oi, na gobbal dy eaishtagh rish coraa Yee. Cre eisht ta eu dy yannoo?—Ta Jee hene ginsh diu; [418] “Jiu, my nee shiu clashtyn e choraa, ny creoi-jee nyn greeaghyn;” kiar-jee dy shickyr, dy jean shiu liorish cooney Yee, veih’n tullogh shoh nyn gooid share dy hauail nyn annym;—dy jean shiu guee gys Jee dy leeideil shiu, dy chooney lhieu, as dy vannaghey er y phayrt euish, as dy yannoo ny ta shiu er chiarail; as bee-jee shickyr dy bee yn Spyrryd Noo meriu, dy leeideil, dy chooney lhieu, as dy gherjaghey shiu.
English: Therefore, if there be any of you, who are sensible that you have hitherto lived a careless, unchristian life;—if you are afraid of what will follow, and do wish that you had taken up sooner;—if you are convinced that the judgments of God against sinners are terrible and true;—and do seriously wish that you were in a safer condition;—then consider, that these being thoughts tending towards repentance, are from the good Spirit of God;—that none of his motions are in vain, but when people wilfully oppose them, or refuse to hear the voice of God. What then have you to do? God himself directs you; “To-day, if you will hear his voice, harden not your hearts;” resolve, that by the help of God, you will from this moment do what you can to save your soul;—that you will pray to God to direct, to assist, and to bless your endeavours, and do what you resolve; and be assured the Holy Ghost will be with you, to guide, to help, and to comfort you.

Manx: Quoi-erbee ny mast’ ain ta treishteil echey gys Jee, as credjal dy vel eh ayns raad y vea, lhisagh eh goail huggey hene, tra ta’n Scriptyr loayrt mychione coyrt sneih er y Spyrryd Noo, dy vel yh cur roin, dy vel yh possibyl dooin dy yannoo lheid ny reddyn as oddys geginaghey eh dy aagail shin.
English: Whoever amongst us has hopes towards God, and believes himself in the way of life, ought to consider, that when the Scripture speaks of grieving the Holy Spirit, it does intimate to us, that it is possible for us to do such things as may force him from us.

Manx: Nyn gurrym eisht yh, dy yeeaghyn dy kiaralagh da nyn raaidyn; as, myr ta shin treishteil son saualtys, gyn y daanys y ghoail orrin dy hannaghtyn ayns geiyrt da pecca erbee er-fys; agh my ta shin goit giare, dy eanaghtyn ji’n-hene yn queshtion shoh,—Vel yn pecca shoh ta mee er ve oolee jeh cordail rish my hreishteil son myghin ec y laa mooar? Cha vel; as shen-y-fa sheign dou scarrey rish, er-nonney scarrey rish my hreishteil jeh Flaunys.
English: Our duty then is, to be careful of our ways; and, as we hope for salvation, not to dare to continue in the practice of any known vice; but if we are overtaken, to ask ourselves this question,—Is this sin I have been guilty of consistent with my hopes of mercy at the great day? It is not; and therefore I must part with it, or part with my thoughts of Heaven.

Manx: As bee-jee shickyr jeh, eshyn nagh lhoys resooney myr shoh rish e chree, cha vel foast aigney mooar echey gys y vea Chreestee, agh [419] t’eh ayns danjere ve mollit ayns e hreishteil jeh niau.
English: And, be assured, he that dares not thus reason with his heart is not yet well in love with a Christian life, but is in danger of being disappointed of his hopes of Heaven.

Manx: Voish ny ta er ve rait, ta shiu fakin cre ta Jee er n’yannoo er nyn son, roish my row shin abyl dy yannoo monney er nyn son hene.
English: [463]  From what has been said, you see what God has done for us, before we were able to do any thing for ourselves.

Manx: T’eh er ghoail shin stiagh gys conaant,—er choyrt dooin e Ghoo Casheric as e Hacramentyn,—er n’yannoo dooin gialdynyn erskyn-towse mooar as ooasle,—as er hoiaghey rhimbi’n yn eiyrtys atchimagh jeh soiaghey beg jeu.
English: He has received us into Covenant,—given us his Holy Word and Sacraments,—made us many great and precious promises,—and set before us the dreadful consequence of neglecting them.

Manx: Ta shiu fakin myrgeddin, dy vel nish red ennagh dy ve jeant liorinyn, dy vod mayd jannoo shickyr jeh foayr as cooney yn Spyrryd Casheric shoh.
English: You see likewise, that now something is to be done by us, that we may secure the favour and assistance of this Holy Spirit.

Manx: Sheign dooin freayl shin-hene oltyn glen as firrinagh jeh Agglish Chreest;—cha nheign dooin geiyrt eh voin, liorish drogh chooyrse erbee dy phecca, as cha nheign dooin cur shaghey caaghyn erbee cour gaase ayns grayse, ta Jee er phointeil as nee eh foardrail dooin.
English: We must keep ourselves pure and undefiled members of Christ’s Church. We must not drive him from us, by any wicked course of sinning; and we must omit no opportunities of growing in grace, which God has appointed and shall afford us.

Manx: Sheign dooin lhaih na clashtyn e Ghoo Casheric;—
English: We must read or hear his Holy Word;—

Manx: Sheign dooin kiarail y ghoail dy reayl dy casheric lheid ny laghyn as ta soit er-lheh son y chirveish echeysyn;—
English: we must take care to keep holy such days as are set apart for his service;—

Manx: Sheign dooin goll dy kinjagh gys e hie, as dy kinjagh goail-rish dy nee er’syn ta nyn [420] marrant, liorish guee gys Jee son ny ta shin feme, as liorish coyrt booise da son ny ta shin dy gheddyn;—
English: we must go constantly to his house, and constantly acknowledge our dependence upon him, by praying to God for what we want, and by giving him thanks for what we receive;—

Manx: As sheign dooin ve shickyr dy ghoail yn Sacrament Casheric jeh Shibber y Chiarn, nee ooraghey as niartaghey nyn anmeenyn, cooid ta, er-y-fa shen, ayns aght er-lheh enmyssit ny haase dy ghrayse.
English: and we must be sure to receive the Holy Sacrament of the Lord’s Supper, which is the strength and refreshment of our souls, and is therefore in an especial way called a means of grace.

Manx: Nish, my nee mayd ny reddyn shoh myr lhisagh shin, lesh cree onneragh, shoh vees yn eiyrtys:
English: Now, if we do these things as we ought, with an honest heart, this will be the effect.

Manx: Hoshiaght; Bee mayd feer imlee, myr ta fys ain nagh vel veg ain lhien hene dy yannoo boggys ass:- Son my ta mish ny share na peiagh elley, she yn Spyrryd Noo ta er n’yannoo mee myr shen, neayr as dy vel shin ooilley co-like er nyn ruggey ayns pecca, as ooilley co-like er nyn laadey lesh.
English: First; we shall be very humble, knowing that we have nothing of our own to boast of. For if I differ from another, it is the Holy Ghost that has made the difference, we being all equally born in sin, and all equally liable to be over-run with it.

Manx: ’Sy nah ynnyd; Bee mayd feer chiaralagh jeh nyn raaidyn, liorish cooinaghtyn, dy vel shin fo leeideilys as reiltys Spyrryd Casheric, vees seaghnit dy akin shin almoragh as meerioosagh tra ta nyn anmeenyn veayn ayns gaue.
English: Secondly; we shall all be very careful of our ways, remembering, that we are under the direction and government of an Holy Spirit, who will be grieved to see us thoughtless and negligent when our immortal souls lie at stake.

Manx: Er-jerrey; Bee mayd feer wooisal dy gooidsave lesh Jee dy yannoo soiagh ji’n as dy hauail shin er conaantyn erbee;—as dy bee yn Spyrryd mie echeysyn dy kinjagh marin, dy reayl shin ayns y raad lhisagh shin goll,—dy hayrn back shin tra ta shin gimmeeaght [421] dy aggairagh,—dy endeil shin noi nyn noidyn pooaral,—dy nyn gummal seose, dy nyn gherjaghey, as ec dy chooilley hraa dy chemmyrkey shin:—Lhisagh shoh gientyn aynin lheid yn ennaghtyn booisal as nagh vel shin abyl fockley-magh, agh liorish slane biallys da ny saraghyn echeysyn.
English: Lastly; we shall be very thankful that God is pleased to accept and save us upon any terms, but that his good Spirit will ever be present with us, to keep us in the way we should go,—to pull us back when we go wrong,—to defend us against our powerful enemies,—to support, to comfort, and at all times to succour us. This ought to create in us such a sense of gratitude as we are not able to express, but by an entire obedience to his commands.

Manx: As yn Spyrryd bannee shen, voishyn ta cheet dy chooilley ghioot mie as firrinagh, dy jean eh tannaghtyn orrin as cummal marin son dy bragh;—dy vreill eh shin ayns unnaneys yn Agglish;—dy d’annee eh dooin ny saaseyn dy ghrayse;—dy scugh eh foddey voin dy chooilley vee-hushtey, creoghys cree, as soiaghey beg jeh Goo Yee;—dy vod mayd lesh meenid as gerjagh, roi yn race ta soit kiongoyrt rooin, dy shickyr credjal dy vel dy chooilley nhee gobbraghey cooidjagh son y chooid share dauesyn ta goail aggle roish Jee, trooid Yeesey Creeft nyn Jiarn.
English: And may that blessed Spirit, from whom cometh every good and perfect gift, rest upon us and dwell with us for ever—preserving us in the unity of the church;—continuing to us the means of grace;—removing far from us all ignorance, hardness of heart, and contempt of God's word;—that we may, with patience and comfort, run the race that is set before us; stedfastly believing, that all things shall work together for good to those that fear God, through Jesus Christ our Lord;

Manx: Huggeysyn, marish yn Ayr as yn Spyrryd Noo, dy row dy chooilley ooashley as gloyr, seihl gyn jerrey. Amen.
English: to whom, with the Father and the Holy Ghost, be all honour and glory, world without end. Amen.

Manx: [423] SHARMANE XX.
English: [469] SERMON LXXV.

Manx: Bun as Bree Sacrament Shibber y Chiarn.
English: THE LORD’s SUPPER PRACTICALLY EXPLAINED.

Doce me, Domine Jesu, sacrum hoc institutum tali sacro modo tractare , et conatus meos gratia tua adeo secunda, ut indignus usus corporis et sanguinis tui judicium, meum aut eorum qui me audient, nunquam aggravet; sed sacrificii tui memores semper digni fieremus participes. Amen.
Notes: The Latin prayer at the beginning of this sermon was not translated into Manx.

Manx: LUKE xxii. 19.
English: LUKE xxii. 19.

Manx: GOAN YEESEY CREEST TRA DOARDEE EH SACRAMENT SHIBBER Y CHIARN.
English: The Words of Jesus Christ when he ordained the Sacrament of the Lord’s Supper:—

Manx: Shoh jean-jee ayns cooinaghtyn jeem’s.
English: This do in remembrance of me
See Deut. xvi. 12. John vi , 26 , 51 , 53 , 55. 1 Cor. x . 16. 1 John i . 7. ii . 28 .

Manx: TA’N Noo Paul cur jerrey er e chied screeuyn gys ny Corinthianee lesh ny goan cronnal shoh:—My ta dooinney erbee nagh vel graih echey er y Chiarn Yeesey Creest, lhig da ve anathema maran-atha.
English: ST. PAUL concludes his first epistle to the Corinthians with these remarkable words: if any man love not the lord Jesus Christ, let him be anathema maranatha.—

Manx: Nish, my oddys yn bunnys dy Chreesteenyn clashtyn ny goan shoh fegooish ve er-creau, sheign da ve edyr son nagh vel ad toiggal, na goail gys cree ad. Son ta’n meanal as yn ynsagh shoh:—My ta Creestee erbee ny mast’ eu soilshaghey liorish e vea as e ymmyrkey, nagh vel graih echey er y Chiarn Yeesey, lhig da lheid y dooinney shen ve giarit magh veih nyn sheshaght Chreestee, son dy vel eh fo corree Yee Ooilley-niartal.
English: Now, if the generality of Christians can hear these words without trembling, it must be, either because they do not understand, or they do not consider them. For the meaning and the direction is this:—If any Christian amongst you shews by his life and behaviour, that he does not love the Lord Jesus, let such a man be separated from your communion, as being under the displeasure of Almighty God.

Manx: [424]    Go’ym orrym dy ghra, nagh nhimmey Creestee, tra t’ad clashtyn ny goan shoh, ta smooinaghtyn dy vel ad veg bentyn roo-hene. Ta shin ooilley agh ro aarloo dy aurys yn chooid share my-nyn-gione hene, as dy smooinaghtyn yh neu-phossibyl gyn dy choyrt graih da Yeesey Creest, liorish e hoilchinys as pleadeilys er nyn son ta shin treishteil dy ve er nyn sauail.
English: I dare say, that few Christians, when they hear these words, do think themselves at all concerned in them. We are all but too apt to conclude the best for ourselves, and to think it impossible not to love Jesus Chrift, by whose merits and mediation we hope to be saved.

Manx: Agh nagh lhig dooin molley shin-hene.—Lhig dooin ny s’leaie, fenaghtyn dy chooilley ghooinney jeh hene,—Kys ta mee gymmyrkey mee-hene dauesyn ta er n’yannoo thurnyn peiagh-mooinjerey orrym, as dauesyn shynney lhiam dy jarroo? My ta dooinney erbee er n’yannoo thurn feer ymmyrchagh orrym,—my ta dooinney erbee er n’ghialdyn ard foayr erbee dou,—shynney lhiam loayrt jeh hene, as jeh’n chenjallys t’eh er hoilshaghey, na er n’ghialdyn dou;—ta mee dy mennic smooinaght er, as shen lesh aigney booisal,—as ta mee dy slane kiarit gyn dy bragh dy yannoo nhee erbee oddys corree y chur er.
English: But let us not deceive ourselves. Let us rather, every man ask himself,—How is it that I behave myself to my benefactors, and to those whom I do really love? If any man has done me a very great service,—if a man has promised me any great favour,—I love to speak of him, and of the kindness he has done, or promised me;—I often think of him, and with a thankful mind,—and I fully resolve never to do any thing which may disoblige him.

Manx: Nee shoh myr ta nyn ghraih gys Yeesey Creest? Dy baillish Jee dy voddagh shin ooilley lesh firrinys gra dy nee shoh myr t’yh. Agh myr shoh na gyn, lhig dooin consideral cre t’eh er n’yannoo er nyn son, as goail tastey cre’n greme nee yh goail er nyn greeaghyn,
English: Is it thus we love the Lord Jesus Christ? Would to God we could all truly say so. However, let us consider what he has done for us, and see how it will affect our hearts.

Manx: [425]  Tra va slane sluight sheelnaue fo corree Yee Ooilley-niartal,—tra v’ad er choayl dy chooilley chairys gys maynrys dy bragh beayn, as fagit mooie cour yn baase dy bragh farraghtyn,—ghow Yeesey Creest er hene dy chosney pardoon dooin, as dy aa-choyrt shin ayns foayr rish Jee.
English: [470]  When the whole race of mankind was under the displeasure of Almighty God,—had forfeited all pretence to immortal happiness, and had become liable to eternal death,—Jesus Christ undertook to obtain our pardon, and to restore us to the favour of God.

Manx: Agh va’n pecca er skeayley choud as cha lhean shen, nagh voddagh shoh ve jeant fegooish lhiassaghey ve er ny yannoo da cairys Yee. Va Jee er vockley magh, dy beagh mee-viallys Adam er ny cherraghey lesh baase. Va ynrickys Yee lhie er shoh, as va’n oiljagh, as ooilley e lhuight, fo e yymmoose.
English: But the sin had spread so far and wide, that this could not be done without a suitable satisfaction to the justice of God. God had declared, that the disobedience of Adam should be punished with death. His truth was at stake, and the offender, and all his posterity, were under his displeasure.

Manx: Shen-y-fa, ren Yeesey Creest, meiyhit lesh chymmey son lheid y treihys vooar, fagail gloyr niau, as ghow eh er yn dooghys ainyn, dy voddagh eh, myr dooinney, surranse ny va ny peccaghyn ainyn er doilloo, as, myr Mac Yee, dy voddagh yn lhiassagh’ ve fondagh son peccaghyn yn seihl ooilley. Ayns fockle, hug eh sheese e vioys er nyn son; as liorish yn oural smoo feeu shen, ren eh cha nee ynrycan nyn shee rish Jee, as livrey shin veih baase dy bragh farraghtyn; agh choassyn eh veih Jee e Ayr shickyrys jeh bea as maynrys braa da nyn lheid ooilley as harragh dy ve sharvaantyn jeidjagh da.
English: Jesus Christ, therefore, moved with compassion for so great a calamity, left the glories of Heaven, and took upon him our nature, that, as man, he might suffer what our sins had deserved, and that, as the Son of God, the satisfaction might be sufficient for the sins of the whole world. In short, he laid down his life for us; and, by that most worthy sacrifice, he not only made our peace with God, and delivered us from eternal death; but obtained of God his Father an assurance of eternal life and happiness for all such as would become his faithful servants.

Manx: As dy voddagh courey ve orroo shoh harrish ooilley elley, doardee eh Oardagh Casheric, dy reayl seose cooinaghtyn jeh ny ard [426] vannaghtyn shoh derrey’n cheet echey reesht; cur’magh ooilley e eiyrtyssee jeidjagh,—ooilley ny ta treishteil son bannaght erbee liorish e vaase,—dy reayl seose cooinaghtyn jeh’n chooid cheddin ’syn aght ren eh-hene pointeil yn oie my hur eh.
English: And that such might be distinguished from all others, he appointed an Holy Ordinance, to preserve the memory of these mighty blessings till his coming again requiring all his faithful followers,—all who expect any benefit by his death,—to commemorate the same after the manner he ordained the night before he suffered.

Manx: Lhig dooin fenaght jeh nyn greeaghyn hene,—Vel yn vyghin shoh toilloo dy ve freilt ayns cooinaghtyn liorinyn?—Na jir Creestee erbee, dy vel graih echey er y Chiarn Yeesey Creest, nee dy eddrym chyndaa e chooyl er yn oardagh casheric shen, ren Creest hene pointeil, myr yn aght s’booisal dy hoilshaghey nyn ghraih dasyn, as nyn giarail dy hannaghtyn nyn sharvaantyn firrinagh da, son ny myghinyn t’eh er stowal orrin.
English: Let us ask our own hearts,—Does this mercy deserve to be remembered by us?—Or will any Christian say, that he loves the Lord Jesus Christ, who will lightly turn his back upon that holy ordinance, which Christ himself has appointed, as the most acceptable way of shewing our love to him, and our resolution to continue his faithful servants, for his mercies bestowed upon us .

Manx: As dy jarroo son yn oyr shoh ve dy doardee Yeesey Creest yn Sacrament Casheric shoh, dy voddagh Creesteenyn, liorish ve dy mennic cuirt, as kainlt dy chooinaghtyn er graih nyn Saualtagh hooar baase er nyn son,—e hurranse sharroo,—er oyr e vaaish,—yn treihys t’ad er haghney,—as yn vaynrys t’eh er chosney er nyn son,—dy voddagh ad graih y choyrt dasyn lesh ooilley nyn gree as annym;—as liorish jannoo shoh cha mennic as veagh caa oc, dy voddagh nyn ghraih bishaghey gys jerrey nyn mea.
English: And indeed it was for this reason that Jesus Christ ordained this Holy Sacrament, that Christians, being often called upon, and obliged to remember the love of their dying Saviour,—his bitter passion,—the occasion of his death,—the misery they have escaped,—and the happiness he has purchased for them,—might love him with all their heart and soul;—and that, doing this as often as ever they should have an opportunity, their love might increase unto their lives’ end.

Manx: Nagh voddagh peiagh er-y-fa shen smooinaghtyn, fegooish neu-ghiastyllys vooar [427] erbee, nyn lheid as ta dy eddrym chyndaa nyn gooyl er yn oardagh casheric shoh, nagh vel ad dy jarroo graihagh er y Chiarn Yeesey, as, cordail rish sarey yn Noo Paul, dy lhisagh ad ve anathema, ta shen, giarit magh veih sheshaght ny credjuee.
English: May not one therefore conclude, without any great uncharitableness, that such as do lightly run their backs upon this ordinance, do not indeed love the Lord Jesus, and that, according to St. Paul’s direction, they ought to be anathema, that is, separated from the communion of the faithful.

Manx: As ga dy beagh shoh ’sy traa t’ayn nish enmyssit briwnys geyre, ny-yeih shoh va cliaghtey yn agglish ayns toshiaght Creesteeaght, as va shoh cordail rish y leigh va mychione freayl y Chaisht, yn courey mooar jeh baase Chreest, as liorish sarey geyre Yee; [Earrooyn ix. 13.] ta shen, quoi-erbee yinnagh slheh er freayl yn Chaisht, ayns cooinaghtyn jeh nyn livreys ass Egypt, dy beagh yn annym shen er ny ghiarey magh veih pobble Israel.
English: And though this would be called great severity at this time, yet this was the practice of the primitive church, and it was agreeable to the Law of the Passover, the great figure of Christ’s death, and by God's express command, [Numb. ix. 13.] that is, that whoever did neglect to observe the Passover, in remembrance of their deliverance out of Egypt, that soul should be cut off from among the people of Israel.

Manx: As dy feer, Creestee ta toiggal as goail gys cree ard scansh yn Oardagh shoh, as nagh vel er ny lhiettal liorish drogh oaish erbee, na nagh vel er duittym ayns pecca scammyltagh ennagh, cha jean eh ny smoo chyndaa e chooyl er Boayrd y Chiarn, na by-lhoys da gobbal yn Jee chroo eh, na yn Saualtagh ren eh y chionnaghey-reesht.
English: And verily, a Christian, who understands and considers the importance of this Ordinance, and is not hindered by some very evil habit, or by having fallen into some scandalous sin, will no more turn his back upon the Lord’s Table, than he will dare to deny the God that made him, or the Saviour who redeemed him.

Manx: T’ad shoh whilleen resoon dy hoilshaghey yn ard scansh, yn bannaght ta liorish, as yn feme ta rish freayl yn Oardagh shoh, nagh lhiass veg arragh ve currit stiagh da nyn lheid as ta fo imnea firrinagh son nyn saualtys.
English: Here are so many reasons to shew the importance, the blessing, and the necessity of observing this Ordinance, that it will be needless to urge any more to such as have any true concern for their salvation.

Manx: [428]   Myr ta shoh, er-y-fa shen, ny churrym as oardagh, liorish ta dy chooilley Chreestee kainlt myr t’eh jerkal rish saualtys—dy hoilshaghey e ghraih gys Creest, liorish freayl cooinaghtyn er e vaase ’syn aght t’eh hene er phointeil, sheign da’n currym, dy firrinagh-focklagh, ve lheid shen as oddys dy chooilley Chreestee, eer yn er sloo ynsit, toiggal as jannoo dy feeu.
English: This, therefore, being a duty and ordinance, which every Christian is obliged to as he hopes for salvation,—to shew his love of Christ, by commemorating his death after the manner he has appointed,—the duty must, of necessity, be such as every [471] Christian, even the most unlearned, is capable of understanding, and performing worthily.

Manx: As dy jarroo shen myr t’yh. Son myr va’n Israelite sloo ynsit fo’n Leigh, tra ve sarit dy chur lesh e oural gys yn altar, dy chur e laue er kione y vaagh, goail-rish e loghtyn harrish; [Levit. i. 4.] As myr ve dy aashagh toiggal, dy row shoh cour coyrt eh ayns cooinaghtyn, dy nee baase va’n kerraghey cair da pecca,—dy row eh-hene er hoilloo yn baase va cour yn cretoor shen,—dy nee myghin vooar dy Yee v’yh eh dy yannoo soiagh jeh lheid yn oural son y pecca echeysyn, cooid ny-yeih va treisht vie echey dy jinnagh eh, neayr as dy nee eh-hene doardee yh:—Myr yinnagh eh dy feer aashagh toiggal, dy row ooilley shoh kiarit myr oyr feer vreeoil dy injillaghey eh-hene kiongoyrt rish Jee;—dy choyrt feoh da pecca, nagh voddagh leih ve ny chour fegooish coayl bioys cretoor gyn loght; as, er-jerrey, dy row shoh kiarit dy leeideil eh dy ve graihagh er Jee, eh va booiagh dy ve coardit rish er lheid ny conaantyn graysoil:—Ta mee gra, oddagh yn Israelite s’neu-ynsit [429] toiggal yn oyr shoh dy ourallyn, as jannoo yn currym va shirrit er, chiart cha mie as yn fer-ynsee smoo ayns Israel.
English: And indeed so it is. For as the most unlearned Israelite under the Law, when he was commanded to bring his sacrifice to the altar, to lay his hand upon the head of the beast, confessing his sins over him; [ Lev. i. 4.] As he did very easily understand, that this was to put him in mind, that death was the punishment due to sin,—that he himself deserved the death that that creature was going to suffer,—that it was great mercy in God that he would accept such a sacrifice for his sin, which yet he had good hopes he would do, since he himself had ordained it:—As he would very easily perceive, that all this was designed, as a very powerful motive, to humble him before God;—to give him an abhorrence of sin, which could not be forgiven without the loss of the life of an innocent creature;—and, lastly, that it was intended to lead him to the love of God , who would be reconciled to him upon such gracious terms. I say, the most ignorant Israelite could understand this end of sacrifices, and perform the duty required of him, as well as the most learned master in Israel.

Manx: Eer myrgeddin dy chooilley Chreestee, eer yn er sloo ynsit, t’yh ’sy ’phooar dy hoiggal (mannagh bee yh ooilley-dy-lhearagh e oill hene) as dy yannoo dy chooilley churrym ta kainlt er goaldagh feeu jeh Shibber y Chiarn.
English: Even so, every Christian, even the most unlearned, is capable of understanding (if it be not plainly his own fault) and of performing all the duties of a worthy communicant.

Manx: Son tra t’yh er ny insh da dy nee shoh yn oural firrinagh Chreestee,—yn ynrycan saase dy yannoo nyn bersoonyn as ooilley nyn badjeryn booisal gys Jee,—dy gheddyn pardoon son nyn beccaghyn, cooney grayse Yee, as maynrys dy bragh farraghtyn lurg baase;—Tra t’eh fakin shen jeant kiongoyrt rish e hooillyn ren Yeesey Creest eh-hene jannoo; quoi, yn oie cheddin ayn ve er ny vrah, liorish livrey eh-hene seose myr chebbal as oural da Jee son peccaghyn yn seihl ooilley, ren goardaghey yn Sacrament Casheric shoh, liorish goail Arran as Feeyn, as bannaghey ad, as jannoo ad liorish yn bannaght shen, co-soylaghyn firrinagh jeh’n Corp as yn Uill echeysyn, ayns bree as pooar, chamma as ayns ennym:
English: For when he is informed, that this is the true Christian sacrifice,—the only means of rendering our persons and all our prayers acceptable to God, of obtaining the pardon of our sins, the assistance of God’s grace, and everlasting happiness after death. When he sees that done before his eyes that Jesus Christ himself did,—who, the same night in which he was betrayed, having devoted himself an offering and a sacrifice to God for the sins of the whole world, did institute this Holy Sacrament, by taking Bread and Wine, and blessing them, and making them, by that blessing, the true representatives of his Body and Blood, in virtue and power, as well as in name.

Manx: Tra ta’n Creestee geddyn baght, dy row yn shirveish shoh oardrit liorish Creest hene, cha nee ny lomarcan myr courey [fenishagh] jeh e ard ghraih da e chretooryn boghtey, agh son saase liorish yinnagh eh chymney huc ooilley bannaghtyn yn baase shen v’eh ec y [430] traa shen mysh surranse; as liorish yinnagh eshyn lhiantyn toilchinys e vaase da ooilley pobble as eashyn y theihl:—
English: —When he is made sensible, that this service was ordained by Christ himself, not only as a testimony of his great love for his poor creatures, but as a means whereby he would communicate all the benefits of that death which he was then going to suffer; and by which he would apply the merits of his death to all people and ages of the world.

Manx: Er-jerrey; tra ta shickyrys echey, eer veih Creest hene, (Ean vi. 56.) dy vel eshyn ta gee as giu shoh e eill as uill ’syn aght casheric shoh, dy vel eh beaghey ayns Creest as Creest aynsyn; dy vel cairys ec y lheid shoh gys y vea veayn, as dy jean Jee y hroggal seose eh ec y laa jerrinagh.
English: —Lastly; when he is assured, even from Christ himself, [John vi. 26.] that whoso eateth and drinketh this his Flesh and Blood after this holy manner, dwelleth in Christ and Christ in him; that such a one has a right to eternal life, and that God will raise him up at the last day.

Manx: Lhig da dooinney, ta mee gra, ve lesh yn ynsagh sloo, ny-yeih nee eh dy aashagh toiggal,—Nagh vel eh dy yeeaghyn er, na dy ghoail yn Arran as Feeyn shoh myr beaghey cadjin, agh myr couraghyn casheric jeh Corp as Fuill Chreest, jeant y lheid liorish bannaght er-lheh Yee er;—Dy vel eh dy ghoail yh ayns cooinaghtyn jeh baase Chreest, as dy chredjal son firrinys, dy bee bannaght Yee marish e yannoo myr shen; son myr dy nee Oardagh Yee hene yh, cha vod eh agh e vannaght y choyrt er, as er’syn ta tastagh da.
English: Let a man, I say, be never so unlearned, yet he will easily understand, that he is not to look upon, and receive this Bread and Wine as common food, but as holy representatives of Christ’s Body and Blood, made such by an especial blessing of God. That he is to receive it in remembrance of the death of Christ, and to believe assuredly, that the blessing of God will attend his doing so; for it being God’s own Ordinance, he cannot but bless it, and him who observes it.

Manx: As tra t’yh er ny insh da, dy ren nyn Jiarn Yeesey Creest sarey yn shirveish shoh dy ve freilt seose derrey harragh eh reesht, (ta shen, dy vriwnys y theihl) nee eh dy aashagh briwnys, dy lhisagh eh kiarail eh-hene cour yn laa shen, liorish yn Oardagh Casheric shoh, dy vod eh meeteil e Hiarn as Briw myr carrey, ec y voayrd raad t’eh er ve cha mennic er ny ghoail stiagh lesh oltagh bea.
English: And when he is informed, that the Lord Jesus commanded this service to be observed until his coming again, (that is, to judge the world) he will easily conclude, that he ought to prepare himself against that day, by this Holy Ordinance, that he may meet his Lord and Judge as a friend, at whose table he has been so often received and entertained.

Manx: [431]   Nee Creestee, ta mee gra reesht, lhig da ve lesh cha beg dy ynsagh as oddys y ve, dy aashagh fakin, dy vel yn Sacrament Casheric shoh smoo cooie dy yannoo eh aarloo son yn laa mooar shen, as yn coontey ta er ec y traa shen dy choyrt;—dy vel yh kiarit dy injillagh eh, —dy hayrn eh gys arrys,—dy chur er ve ayns aggle dy choyrt jymmoose er Jee,—as dy yannoo eh feer vooisal son ooilley e vyghinyn.
English: A Christian, I say again, let him be never so unlearned, will easily see, that this Holy Sacrament is most proper to prepare him for that great day, and the account he is then to give;—that it is designed to humble him,—to bring him to repentance, to make him fearful of offending God,—and to make him very thankful for all his mercies.

Manx: Ver yh dy mennic ayns cooinaghtyn eh jeh eiyrtys treih tuittym Dooinney, as jeh’n phecca haink liorish; neayr as nagh jinnagh oural veg sloo na baase Chreest lhiassaghey y yannoo gys cairys Yee.
English: It will put him often in mind of the sad effects of the Fall of Man, and of the sin occasioned thereby; since no less a sacrifice than the death of Christ would satisfy the justice of God.

Manx: Nee eh dy aashagh fakin cre sheign da jerkal rish, my t’eh beaghey as geddyn baase ayns pecca nagh vel arrys goit jeh, eer yn kerraghey s’trimmey.
English: He will easily see what he must expect, if he lives and dies [472] in sin unrepented of, even the severest punishment.

Manx: Nee eh dy aashagh cur-my-ner, dy vel ad shoh nyn gaaghyn bannee, as gyn dy ve caillit, jeh jannoo ass-y-noa e chonaant bashtee, cooid ta fys echey dy vel eh er vrishey, as dy yannoo e hee rish Jee.
English: He will easily perceive, that these are blessed opportunities, and never to be lost, of renewing his baptismal covenant, which he knows he has broken, and of making his peace with God.

Manx: Son cha vod eh ve agh slane toiggalagh dy nheign da ve ny red feer vooisal da’n Ard-ooashley Flaunyssagh, dy chur stiagh kiongoyrt rishyn baase e Vac, hur baase dy chionnaghey shin reesht, as dy aa-choyrt shin ayns foayr rish, guee er dy chooinaghtyn ayns [432] niau er baase e Vac, son yn foays ainyn, myr ta shinyn er y thalloo ayns biallys da’n sarey echeysyn.
English: For he cannot but be convinced, that it must be one of the most prevailing arguments with the Divine Majesty, to represent unto him the death of his Son, who died to redeem us, and to restore us to his favour, beseeching him to remember his Son’s death in Heaven, for our good, as we do on earth in obedience to his command.

Manx: As er-jerrey, sheign da Creestee, lesh yn eer ynsagh sloo, toiggal as gennaghtyn, myr s’men’key t’eh chebbal eh-hene fenish Yee, dy phleadeil [ass e lhieh hene] baase e Vac, ayns yn aght crauee shoh, wheesh shen s’booisal vees yh gys Jee, wheesh shen smoo dy ghrayse nee eh geddyn voish, wheesh shen s’troshey vees e chredjue, e hreishteil ny shickyree, as ny s’lajer e phardoon.
English: And, lastly, a Christian, let him be never so unlearned, must know, and be convinced, that the oftener he presents himself before God, to plead his Son’s death , in this holy manner, the more pleasing it will be to God, the more graces he will receive from him, the stronger will be his faith, the surer his hopes, and the firmer his pardon.

Manx: Nee eh myrgeddin dy feer aashagh fakin, cre ny cur’myn ta lhie er dy yannoo eh ny ghoaldagh feeu jeh’n Sacrament Shoh.
English: He will also very easily see, what duties are required to make him a worthy receiver of this Sacrament.

Manx: Nee eh toiggal, son mac-soyley, nagh vod shirveish cha crauee, as shirveish er ta’n saualtys echey lhie, nagh vod yh ve jeant fegooish smooinaghtyn as kiarail ennagh.
English: He will understand, for instance, that so solemn a service, and a service upon which his salvation depends, cannot be well performed without some thoughts and consideration.

Manx: As nee kiarail nagh nee mooar, slane toiggal y choyrt da, dy nheign da goail-rish as treigeil ny peccaghyn shen, chost da Yeesey Creest e vioys, dy yannoo stiagh rish Jee dy phardooney ad;—dy vel eh dy gholl gys y Chreestiaght lesh slane kiarail dy leeideil bea Creestee;—my t’eh jannoo shen, dy vod eh jerkal gys myghin Yee trooid Yeesey Creest; dy lhisagh yn chooinaghtyn jeh baase Chreest ve feer deyr da;—as dy vel eh kainlt dy leih, as dy chur graih, as dy yannoo mie da [433] feallagh elley, neayr as dy vel Jee cha mie as cha dooie dasyn.
English: And a very little consideration will convince him, that he must confess and forsake those sins, which cost Jesus Christ his life, to prevail with God to pardon them;—that he is to go to the Sacrament with a full purpose of leading a Christian life;—that if he does so, he may depend upon God’s mercy through Jesus Christ; that the remembrance of Christ’s death ought to be very dear to him;—and that he is bound to forgive, and to love, and to do good to, others, since God is so good and so kind to him.

Manx: Sheign da dy chooilley Chreestee fakin, as goail-rish yn feme ta rish yn aarlaghey shoh; as dy jean quoi-erbee ta dy daaney goll gys Boayrd y Chiarn fegooish lheid yn aarlagh, geddyn mollaght ayns ynnyd bannaght.
English: Every Christian must see, and acknowledge, the necessity of these qualifications; and that whoever goes presumptuously to the Lord’s Table without them, will receive a curse, instead of a blessing.

Manx: Ta mee gra, dy daaney; ta shen, gyn smooinaght, gyn imnea, as fegooish jannoo ny t’eh abyl, dy ve ny ghoaldagh feeu.
English: I say, presumptuously; that is, without thought, without concern, and without doing what he is able, to become a worthy communicant.

Manx: Son shoh nyn gherjagh smoo, nagh vel Jee jerkal rish ny smoo veih dooinney erbee, agh dy yannoo ymmyd onneragh jeh’n towse shen dy ghrayse as soilshey t’eh er choyrt da.
English: For this is our great comfort, that God expects no more of any man, but that he make an honest use of that measure of grace and light which he has given him.

Manx: My ta dooinney jannoo shen, ga dy vod eh ve fo dooyt as aggle, ny-yeih cha vod eh ve ayns danjere, ny smoo na oddys lhiannoo ammyssagh ve ayns danjere veih ayr ta fakin dy vel eh jannoo e chooid share dy wooiys eh.
English: If a man does so, though he may have his scruples, and his fears, yet he cannot be in danger, no more than a dutiful child can be in danger from a father who sees him doing his best to please him.

Manx: Agh, er son wheesh as dy vel ymmodee ro laik dy gholl gys Boayrd y Chiarn fegooish smooinaghtyn dy cooie, as dy vel rour jannoo yn trubbyl jeh feysht as jannoo ad-hene aarloo ny leshtal son gyn goll cha mennic as lhisagh ad, (ta shen, cha mennic as ta caa oc;) bee yh cooie dy chonsideral cre’n aarlaghey ta lhie orroosyn dy yannoo, bailloo goll dy feeu gys Shibber y Chiarn.
English: But, forasmuch as many are apt to go to the Lord’s Table without due consideration, and too many do make the trouble of examining and preparing themselves a reason for their not going so often as they should do, (that is, as often as they have an opportunity;) it will be proper to consider, what preparation is required of those that would go worthily to the Lord’s Supper.

Our Church has indeed given us a short and sure rule and answer to that question, provided we take pains to understand it; but the truth is, it is too often mistaken, both by those that are presumptuous, and by those that are lazy, and not disposed to consider. By the presumptuous, it is made a matter of mere form; and by the lazy it is looked upon as a burthen, and to be avoided as much as possible; both these are greatly mistaken, and betray a very great disregard for their own souls. And this we shall plainly see, now we come to consider, what preparation is required of them who go to the Lord’s Supper.
Notes: This paragraph is not in the Manx translation

Manx: As yn chied chesmad gys aarlaghey cooie t’yh, dy eysht shin hene vel shin dy [434] firrinagh goail arrys son nyn beccaghyn ta er n’gholl shaghey.
English: And the first step to a good preparation is, тo examine ourselves whether we repent us truly of our former sins.

Manx: Nish, t’yh dy ve jerkit, dy row dy chooilley Chreestee, ta er ve ynsit e churrym lesh feeudys erbee, my ghow eh hoshiaght yn Sacrament shoh, jeant toiggalagh jeh meanal as kiarail yn Oardagh shoh; as dy row yh kiarit dy choyrt caa da Creesteenyn dy yannoo ass-y-noa, as dy chur stiagh nyn glaim gys yn Conaant shen ta nyn Yee graysoil er n’yannoo rish dooinney: Yn Conaant cheddin she shoh yh, dy jean Jee, er yn ayrn echeysyn, er nyn arrys, pardooney ooilley nyn beccaghyn,—dy der eh dooin ooilley yn ghrayse as cooney ta ymmyrchagh dy yannoo ny t’eh dy hirrey orrin, as dy jean eh shin maynrey son dy bragh, er conaant dy jean mainyn, er yn ayrn ainyn, treigeil ooilley nyn beccaghyn; dy jean mayd dy ynric streeu dy hea voish dy chooilley nhee ta shin credjal ver jymmoose er Jee, as lesh yn ynrickys cheddin streeu dy yannoo ny t’eh er harey dooin.
English: Now, it is to be hoped, that every Christian, who has had any tolerable instruction, was, before he first received this Sacrament, made sensible of the meaning and design of this Ordinance; and that it was intended to give Christians an opportunity of renewing, and laying claim to, that Covenant which our gracious God has made with man: Which Covenant is, that God, on his part, will, upon our repentance, pardon all our sins,—give us all necessary grace and assistance to do what he [473] requires of us, and make us happy for ever, on condition that we, on our part, do forsake all our sins; that we sincerely endeavour to avoid every thing that we believe will displease God, and with the same sincerity endeavour to do what he has commanded us.

Manx: Yinnagh Creestee erbee, ta er gheddyn toiggal jeh shoh, dy aashagh fakin, cre cha ymmyrchagh as v’yh, dy jinnagh eh feysht eh-hene roish my goghe eh er dy ghoail yn Sacrament shen; ta shen, dy jinnagh eh jeeaghyn stiagh ayns stayd e annym, as fakin, row eh ayns towse mie ennagh, er yn ayrn echeysyn, er vreayl conaantyn yn choardail shoh, ta shen, vel eh er leeideil bea sheelt as Creestee.
English: Any Christian, who was made sensible of this, would easily see, how necessary it was, that he should examine himself before he should presume to receive that Sacrament; that is, that he should look into the state of his soul, and see, whether he had, in any good measure, on his part, observed the conditions of this covenant; that is, whether he had lived a sober and a Christian life.

Manx: [435]   As son wheesh as dy vel lane lhie er yn eysht shoh, eer saualtys nyn anmeenyn,—cha jean Creestee smooinaghtyn yh rour trubbyl dy eysht eh-hene ayns aght ennagh lheid shoh:—
English: And forasmuch as a great deal depends upon this enquiry, even the salvation of our souls,—a Christian will not think it too much trouble to examine himself after some such way as this:

Manx: Vel mee er ghoail aym-pene dy vel yn vea shoh ny stayd dy phrowal;—as dy bee mayd maynrey na treih son dy bragh, rere myr ta shin gymmyrkey shin-hene dy mie na dy olk ’sy theihl shoh?—Dy nee kiarail yn Chredjue Chreestee yh dy yannoo shin casheric, dy vod mayd ve ayns am dy ve maynrey; as dy ren Jee, hug mee gys y theihl, mee y choyrt ayn dy ghloyraghey eh liorish bea chasheric?—Dy vel eh fakin ooilley my yannoo, clashtyn ooilley my ghoan, as fys echey er eer folliaghtyn my chree?—Nagh lhisin er-y-fa shen, er gaue my annym, jannoo nhee erbee ta mee credjal ver jymmoose er?—Dy lhisin graih y choyrt da Jee erskyn dy chooilley nhee, neayr as dy nee huggeysyn ta mee jerkal, as treishteil son maynrys?—My ta mee graihagh er’syn erskyn dy chooilley nhee, nee’m dy kinjagh loayrt jeh lesh yn arrym smoo, ver-ym arrym da e Ennym, da e Ghoo, da e Laa, da e Haggyrtyn, as da dy chooilley nhee ta bentyn da?—As er-jerrey, dy lhisin treishteil ayn,—goail padjer huggey gagh-laa,—coyrt booise da,—as ginjillaghey mee hene gys ooilley e ghellal rhym?
English: —Have I considered,—that this life is a state of trial?—That we are upon our good behaviour; and that we shall be happy or miserable for ever, as we behave ourselves well or ill in this world?—That the design of the Christian religion is, to make us holy, that we may be capable of being happy; and that God, who sent me into the world, sent me to glorify him by an holy life?—That he sees all my actions, hears all my words, and knows the very secrets of my heart?—That therefore I ought not, at the peril of my soul, to do any thing which I believe will displease him?—That I ought to love God above all things, since it is from him I expect, and hope, to be made happy?—That if I do love him above all things, I shall always speak of him with the greatest reverence, honour his Name, his Word, his Day, his Ministers, and every thing that belongs to him?—And lastly, that I ought to trust in him,—to pray to him daily,—to give him thanks,—and to submit to all his dealings with me?

Manx: [436]  My ta fys ec my chree nagh vel mee cha jeidjagh er hastey da ny reddyn shoh as lhisin, as shen-y-fa, nagh vel mee er ghoail aggle roish, as er choyrt graih da, as er choyrt arrym, as ooashley da’n Jee mooar shoh, myr va’n ardooashley echeysyn as my churrym hene dy chiangley orrym; camma eisht, nee’m dy smoo imlee guee son e phardoon, as cooney graysoil, dy vod-ym jannoo yh ny s’jeidjee son y traa ta ry-heet.
English: If I am conscious to myself that I have not considered these things so seriously as I should have done, and consequently, that I have not feared, and loved, and honoured, and worshipped this great God, as his majesty and my duty required me to do; why, then , I shall most humbly beg his pardon, and his gracious assistance, that I may do it better for the time to come.

Manx: As son wheesh as dy lhisin jannoo leigh as aigney Yee, choud as t’yh er-fys dou, rule my vea as my yannoo, t’yh kainlt orrym dy eysht mee-hene, vel mee dy jarroo er n’yannoo shen? Vel mee gys y laa shoh er veaghey ayns pecca erbee er-fys; vel mee er lhie fo drogh oaish erbee, edyr jeh breagyn, na loo, na mee-heeltys, na neu-ghlennid, na jeh gymmyrkey bea lhiastey as jeh beggan faunnoo? Vel mee er n'ymmyrkey mee-hene dy feeudagh da dagh unnane share na mee, as erlheh da my vochillyn-anmey; as vel mee biallagh da faraghyn lowal my ir-oik? Vel mee dy jarroo graihagh er my naboo, as nagh vel mee er n’yannoo assee, coayl na skielley da, edyr ayns e chorp, cooid, na ennym vie; na er ghoail vondeish er edyr e vee-hushtey, na e ymmyrch? Vel mee er ve booiagh lesh my stayd hene, fegooish edyr troo mysh feallagh elley, na streeu dy yannoo yh ny share liorish aghtyn neu-yeeragh ?
English: And forasmuch as I ought to make the law and will of God, as far as it is known to me, the rule of my life and actions, I am bound to examine myself, whether I have really done so? Whether I have not hitherto lived in any known sin; been subject to any evil habit, either of lying, or swearing, or intemperance, or impurity, or an idle and a useless life? Whether I do honour my betters, and especially such as have the care of my soul; and do obey the lawful commands of my superiors? Whether I do indeed love my neighbour, and have neither injured, hurt, or wronged him, in body, goods, or good-name; nor taken advantage either of his ignorance or necessities? Whether I have been content with my condition, neither envying that of others, nor endeavouring to better my own by unjust ways?

Manx: [437]   Nee Creestee ta gennaghtyn eh-hene oolee ayns veg jeh ny reddyn shoh, nee eh, my jed eh gys Boayrd y Chiarn, dy firrinagh goail arrys jeh e phecca; ta shen, nee eh geearree pardoon Yee, as e ghrayse, dy vod eh toiggal as jannoo e churrym ny s’jeidjee, as bee eh dy slane kiarit dy leeideil bea noa, ta shen, bea Creestee.
English: A Christian, who finds himself faulty in any of these things, will, before he goes to the Lord’s Table, sincerely repent of his sin; that is, he will beg God’s pardon, and his grace, that he may know and do his duty more faithfully, most seriously purposing to lead a new, that is, a Christian life.

Manx: Cour shoh, bee eh er e hwoaie dy hea veih dy chooilley violagh gys ny peccaghyn shen smoo aignagh t’eh huc. My t’eh, trooid annoonid na miolagh mooar erbee taghyrt dy huittym ayns pecca, nee eh chelleeragh goail-rish as treigeil yh, as bee eh ny s’kiaralee maghey shen. As, myr ta toiggal echey, fegooish grayse er-lheh Yee dy nee ayns fardail vees ooilley e chiarailyn share, bee imnea er dy hirrey yn ghrayse as cooney shen dy chooilley laa jeh e heihl.
English: In order to this, he will take care to avoid all temptations to such sins as he has been most subject to. If through frailty or any violent temptation, he happen to fall into sin, he will forthwith confess and forsake it, and be more careful for the future. And, knowing that without God’s especial grace all his best purposes will come to nothing, he will be careful to beg that grace and assistance every day of his life.

Manx: As dy vod eh ve ny s’ennaghtagh jeh’n red sloo oddys corree y choyrt er Jee, nee eh streeu dy reayl e chooinsheanse meddey as dooishtagh; as dy reayl arrey er-hene, nagh duit eh gys ny peccaghyn t’eh er ghoail arrys jeu.
English: [474]   And that he may be more sensible of the least thing that may displease God, he will endeavour to keep his conscience tender and awake; and keep a watch over himself, that he may not fall into the sins he has repented of.

Manx: Nish, my ta shoh dy ynric jeant tra ta peiagh hoshiaght goail yn Sacrament shoh, camma, eisht, dy eysht eh-hene dy chooilley cheayrt maghey shen,—t’yh dy chonsideral as jeeaghyn vel e vea er ve cordail rish y toshiaght vie shoh?
English: Now, if this be done sincerely when a person first receives this Sacrament, why, then, to examine himself every time after is to consider and see whether his life has been answerable to this good beginning?

Manx: [438]My t’yh, camma eisht, t’eh, choud as ta bentyn gys e arrys, feer chooie dy ghoail Shibber y Chiarn dy feeu cha mennic as ta caa echey.
English: If so, why then he is, as to his repentance, very well qualified to receive the Lord’s Supper worthily as often as he can have an opportunity.

Manx: Agh, er jeeaghyn stiagh gys stayd e annym, my t’eh feddyn dy vel eh er huittym ayns pecca erbee jeh e yoin, —dy vel eh er ve leeidit erscoyl liorish e hayntyn, as nagh vel eh dy cooie er streeu dy gheddyn yn vainshteragh orroo,—sheign da, myr t’eh treishteil son myghin, goail kiarail dy bee e arrys ny s’ynric; ta shen, sheign da cur eh hene fo kianglaghyn foddey s’geyrey,—sheign da e arrys ve ayns towse ennagh corrym rish yn pecca dy chooyl-skyrraghtyn,—as liorish trostey as gobbal eh-hene, cur er e hyndaa reesht gys pecca ve ny s’agglee as s’neu-aashagh, as bea Creestee dy ve ny s’boggoil, as dy ve er ny reih roish raaidyn phecca, ta feme lheid y medjin sharroo, roish my vod eh treishteil son sauchys.
English: But if, upon looking into the state of his soul, he finds that he has fallen into any wilful sin,—that he has been led away by his lusts, and has used no just endeavours to master them,—he must, as he hopes for mercy, take care that his repentance be more sincere; that is, he must lay himself under much stricter obligations,—he must make his repentance bear some proportion to the sin of backsliding, and, by fasting and self-denial, make his return to sin more frightful and uneasy, and a Christian life more welcome, and to be embraced before the ways of sin, which require so painful a remedy, before he can hope for any safety.

Manx: Yn nah chesmad gys aarlaghey cooie t’yh, dy ronsaghey magh dooghys nyn gredjue, vel ain credjue bioal ayns myghin Yee trooid Creest. Credjue bioal; ta shen, credjue ta glenney yn cree, credjue ta coyrt magh yn mess dy viallys as obbraghyn mie; son shen yn eer vioys dy chredjue, son ta “Credjue fegooish obbraghyn marroo.”
English: The next step to a worthy preparation is, to enquire into the nature of our faith, whether we have a lively faith in God’s mercy through Christ. А lively faith;—that is, a faith which purifies the heart, a faith which produces obedience and good works for that is the very life of faith, “Faith without works being dead.”

Manx: Nish myghinyn Yee gys dooinney trooid Creest t’ad, leih peccaghyn da ooilley ta dy [439] firrinagh goail arrys er nyn son,—cooney e Spyrryd Casheric da nyn lheid ooilley as nagh vel cur corre er liorish nyn ghrogh-yannoo,—as gialdyn shickyr jeh bea as maynrys dy bragh beayn da lheid as ta freayl e annaghyn.
English: Now, God’s mercies to man through Jesus Christ are, forgiveness of sins to all that truly repent of them,—the assistance of his Holy Spirit to all such as do not grieve him by their evil deeds, and a sure promise of eternal life and happiness to such as keep his commandments.

Manx: Foddee dooinney dy jarroo smooinaghtyn dy vel eh credjal ny gialdynyn shoh dy Yee ayns Creest; agh dy feer cha vel eh agh molley e chree hene, mannagh vel e chredjue ceau y vessyn dooghyssagh; as t’ad shen, arrys firrinagh ayns treishteil jeh pardoon,—bea casheric, cooid ny lomarcan oddys shickyraghey dooin sheshaght yn Spyrryd Noo,—as lheid yn yeearree jeean son bea as maynrys braa, as ta cur er dooinney jannoo e chooid share dy gheddyn ad.
English: A man may indeed think that he believes these promises of God in Christ; but certainly he does but deceive his own heart, if his faith has not its natural fruits, which are, a sincere repentance, in hopes of pardon,—an holy life, which alone can secure the fellowship of the Holy Spirit,—and such an earnest desire after eternal life and happiness, as puts a man upon his best endeavours to attain them.

Manx: Shen-y-fa, tra baillish Creestee, cour aarlaghey eh-hene son Shibber y Chiarn, feysht firrinys e chredjue, lhisagh eh fenaght jeh hene queshtionyn ennagh lheid shoh:—Vel gialdynyn Yee jeh pardoon er my arrys er n’obbragh aynym lhiassaghey-bea?—Vel mee feddyn dy vel mee er ve biallagh da Spyrryd mie Yee, liorish yn cooney t’eh er choyrt dou dy leeideil bea noa, ta shen, bea Creestee?—As, er-jerrey, nagh vel mee er ve chyndait veih streeu son y vea veayn, liorish ny caslyssyn foalsey dy vaynrys ta shin meeteil roo ayns shoh?
English: When a Christian, therefore, in order to prepare himself for the Lord’s Supper, would examine into the truth of his faith, he ought to ask himself such questions as these:—Has God’s promise of pardon upon my repentance produced in me amendment of life?—Do I find that I have been governed by God’s good Spirit, by the assistance he has given me to lead a new, that is, a Christian life?—And, lastly, have I not been diverted from labouring after eternal life, by the false appearances of happiness which we meet with here?

Manx: Nee Creestee erbee, nee agh fenaghtyn lheid ny queshtionyn shoh jeh hene, dy [440] aashagh toiggal vel e chredjue ayns myghinyn Yee trooid Creest lheid as lhisagh yh ve; ta shen, vel e chredjue er chur magh ny eiyrtyssyn bannee ec. My ta, eisht t’eh dy kinjagh ayns am son yn Oardagh Casheric shoh.
English: Any Christian, who will but ask himself such questions as these, will easily know whether his faith in the mercies of God through Christ be such as it should be; that is, whether his faith has had its saving effects. If so, then he is always prepared for this Holy Ordinance.

Manx: Yn nah vriaght ta er Creestee dy yannoo t’yh, Vel cooinaghtyn as ennaghtyn booisal echey jeh baase Chreest? As dy jarroo, quoi-erbee nee agh goail echey hene cre cha feer treih as beign da nyn stayd ve, tra nagh jinnagh oural veg sloo lhiassagh gys cairys nyn Yee jymmoosit, as dy aa-choyrt shin ayns foayr rish, na baase e Vac hene: Quoi-erbee nee shoh y ghoail gys cree, cha vod eh agh cooinaghtyn er yn vaase shen lesh cree booisal; neayr as dy gooidsave lesh Jee, er coontey yn oural shen, dy ghoail chymmey er camlaagys nyn n’ghooghys,—dy leih dooin nyn beccaghyn,—dy yeeaghyn orrin myr e chloan hene, —dy choyrt dooin dy chooilley chooney vees mayd feme,—as my nee mayd nyn ymmyrkey myr ta cooie da cloan dasyn, nee eh, er y ghraih echeysyn, jannoo shin maynrey son dy bragh.
English: The next enquiry a Christian is to make is, whether he has a thankful remembrance and sense of Christ’s death? And indeed, whoever will but consider how very sad our condition must needs be, when no less a sacrifice would satisfy the justice of our offended God, and restore us to his favour, than the death of his own Son: Whoever considers this, cannot but remember that death with a very thankful heart; since, on account of that sacrifice, God is pleased to overlook the untowardness of our nature,—to forgive us our sins,—to look upon us as his children,—to give us all the assistance we shall want,—and, if we behave ourselves as becomes his children, he will, for his sake, make us happy for ever.

Manx: Ayns fockle, ta Yeesey Creest, liorish e vaase, er chosney shin veih coayl-anmey.—Quoi-erbee ta goail gys cree meanal yn fockle shen, cha vod eh agh ve feer vooisal. Agh eisht, lhig dooin cooinaghtyn ec y traa cheddin, myr ta shin treishteil fon bannaght erbee liorish e vaase, dy nheign dooin surranse  [441] dasyn dy chosney shin veih’n drogh heihl t’ayn nish,—dy yannoo shin casheric, dy vod mayd ve feeu dy haghney lheid y treihys vooar.
English: [475]   In short, Jesus Christ, by his death, has redeemed us from damnation. Whoever considers the meaning of that word, cannot but be very thankful. But then, let us at the same time remember, that, as we hope for any benefit by his death, we must suffer him to redeem us from this present evil world, to make us holy, that we may become worthy to escape so great a misery.

Manx: Yn vriaght s’jerree lhisagh Creestee jannoo, t’yh shoh, Vel eh ayns graih rish dy chooilley ghooinney? As briaght feer ymmyrchagh vees shoh ry-akin dy ve, tra ta shin cooinaghtyn dy vel yn soiaghey nee Jee y yannoo ji’n, as nyn saualtys, lhie er lheid y ghraih shen y ve ain er dy chooilley ghooinney, as ta cooie da oltyn yn un lught-thie, yn un chorp, as yn un treishteil as credjue.
English: The last enquiry which a Christian ought to make, is this, whether he be in charity with all men? And a very necessary enquiry this will appear to be, when, we remember, that our acceptance with God, and our salvation, depend upon our having such a good-will towards all men, as becomes members of the same family, of the same body, of the same hope and faith.

Manx: Nee dy chooilley Chreestee sheelt, er-y-fa shen, roish my jed eh gys Boayrd y Chiarn, fenaght jeh hene queshtionyn ennagh nyn lheid shoh:—Vel fys aym er persoon erbee da ta mee er n’yannoo aggair, as da lhisin lhiassaghey ’yannoo, choud as ta mee abyl?—Vel noidyn erbee aym, er nyn son nagh vod-ym as nagh vel mee goail padjer, as nagh vel aigney aym dy ve coardit roo, as dy leih daue?—Vel mee arryltagh dy hoil-shaghey myghin as kenjallys da dy chooilley ghooinney, dy vod cairys ve aym gys, as myghin y gheddyn veih Jee?—Vel mee goail orrym dy ghra dy vel ard gheill aym da my annym, as foast smooinaghtyn dy vel shoh conaant ro chreoi?
English: Every serious Christian will, therefore, before he goes to the Lord’s Table, ask himself some such questions as these:—Do I know of any person to whom I bear any grudge or ill-will?—Is there any person whom I have wronged, and to whom I ought to make satisfaction, as far as I am able?—Have I any enemies, for whom I cannot and do not pray, and am not disposed to be reconciled to, and to forgive them?—Am I ready to shew mercy and kindness to men, that I may be entitled to, and receive mercy from God?—Do I pretend to value my soul, and think this too hard a condition?

Manx: Nee’m, er-y-fa shen, dy smoo aggindagh cloasal rish y conaant shoh dy phardoon ta Yeesey Creest er n’oardaghey;—Nee’m guee [442] dy lhieen Jee my chree lesh yn grayse dy hemper erreeishagh;—dy vod-ym beaghey ayns unnaneys, shee, as graih rish ooilley’n seihl.
English: —I will, therefore, most gladly close with this condition of pardon which Jesus Christ has ordained;—I will pray that God will inspire me with the grace of a forgiving temper;—that I may live in union, peace, and charity, with all the world.

Manx: As nish, Chreesteenyn, nee shiu dy aashagh toiggal quoi adsyn ta goll dy neu-feeu gys Boayrd y Chiarn; as ta tayrn briwnyssyn orroo hene son jannoo shen: Eer ooilley nyn lheid as nagh vel ennaghtyn cooie oc jeh’n bannaght ta liorish Fer-chionnee, as shen-y-fa gyn geill na graih firrinagh da Yeesey Creest;—ooilley nyn lheid as ta beaghey ayns pecca erbee er-fys;—ooilley nyn lheid as nagh vel dy shickyr kiarit dy veaghey, as dy ve er nyn reill, liorish leighyn Yee;—ooilley nyn lheid as ta beaghey ayns streeu rish nyn naboonyn;—ooilley nyn lheid as ta er n’yannoo aggair, as nagh vel jannoo lhiassaghey as cooilleen gys rere nyn booar;—er-jerrey, ooilley nyn lheid as ta goll gys y Sacrament trooid eer cliaghtey, as son dy vel y leigh dy hirrey yh, fegooish goail gys cree ny oyryn ta son, as ny vondeishyn ta liorish goail yh:—Ta ooilley nyn lheid shoh goll dy neu-feeu gys Boayrd y Chiarn, as cheet voish fegooish bannaght.
English: And now, Christians, you will easily understand who they are that go unworthily to the Lord’s Table; and who bring judgments upon themselves by doing so. Even all such as have no true sense of the blessing of a Redeemer, and consequently no true value or love for Jesus Christ;—all such as live in any known sin;—all such as are not sincerely resolved to live, and be governed, by the Laws of God;—all such as live at variance with their neighbours;—all such as have done wrong, and do not make restitution and satisfaction according to their power;—lastly, all such as go to the Sacrament in mere compliance with the laws and custom, without considering the ends and benefits of receiving:—All such go unworthily to the Lord’s Table, and return without a blessing.

Manx: Agh cha nee shen y chooid smessey. T’ad tayrn an-ghoo er Oardaghyn Yee, myr nagh row bannaght na grayse erbee lioroo. T’ad creoghey peccee, t’ad niartaghey an-chredjuee, as tayrn neose orroo-hene briwnyssyn shickyr.
English: But that is not the worst. They bring an evil report upon the Ordinances of God, as if no good, no grace, attended them. They harden sinners, confirm infidels, and bring down certain judgments upon themselves.

Manx: [443]   Ayns fockle; cordail rish y ghraih t’ain er Yeesey Creest,—cordail rish y chiarail ta shin goail dy choyrt biallys da e haraghyn,—cordail rish yn ennaghtyn t’ain jeh nyn livreys liorishyn veih pecca as niurin,—cordail rish nyn ghraih da ooilley ny ta eshyn er chionnaghey-reesht, son ooilley e oltyn as lught-thie,—cordail rish shoh t’yh, dy ve shin nyn ghoaldee feeu na neu-feeu.
English: In short; it is according to the love that we have for Jesus Christ,—according to the care we take to obey his commands,—according to the sense we have of our deliverance, by him, from sin and hell,—according to the love we have for all whom he has redeemed, for all his houshold and family,—that we are worthy or unworthy communicants.

Manx: As bee shoh ny share er ny akin, cha nee ny lomarcan liorish ny temperyn lhieu ta shin goll gys y Chreestiaght, agh liorish y vea ta shin leeideil maghey shen. Son cre’n loght eajee sheign da ve, dy gholl gys Boayrd y Chiarn, myr ren Yuaase, er-chee dy vrah nyn Jiarn? Na myr ren ny Hewnyn mee-cheeaylagh shen ren nyn gharmadyn y skeayley roish, as ghow rish, as ren fockley-magh dy nee eshyn va yn Messiah, as queig laa ny lurg shen, ren ad geam as beealeraght son y chrossey eh?
English: And this will best appear, not by the dispositions only with which we go to the Sacrament, but by the life we lead afterwards. For what an horrid crime must it be, to go to the Lord’s Table, as Judas did, in order to betray our Lord? Or, as those unthoughtful Jews did, who spread their garments before him, and owned and proclaimed him for their Messiah, and five days after, called out to have him crucified?
