Manx: As dy feer er yn un aght cheddin t’adsyn dy yannoo, ta mee-ooashlaghey Jee lesh yn un veeall, ayn ren ad gerrit roish shen goail couraghyn e ghraih ayns y Chreestiaght bannit, as lhiggey orroo dy choyrt booise da son yn courey mooar shoh jeh e ghraih gys sheelnaue. Eer ’syn aght cheddin t’adsyn dy yannoo, quoi, jarrood ooilley ny kiarailyn, ny gialdynyn, as brecaraghyn ren ad ec yn altar, ta chyndaa reesht gys nyn shenn oayllyn; [444]as, er reaghey, myr t’ad dy ommijagh smooinaghtyn, rish ooilley nyn shenn feeaghyn goll er nyn doshiaght reesht, fegooish aggle erbee, dy ghoail orroo feeaghyn noa, ayns treishteil dy bee ad miehit daue, yn nah cheayrt hed ad gys Shibber y Chiarn.
English: And so surely do they, who blaspheme God with the same mouth, which a while ago received the pledges of his love in the blessed Sacrament, and pretended to give him thanks for this great instance of his love to mankind. So do they, who, forgetting all the resolutions, the promises, and vows they made at the altar, return again to their usual liberties; and having, as they vainly suppose, cleared off all old scores, go on, without any scruple, to contract new ones, in hopes of having them easily forgiven, the next time they shall go to the Lord’s Supper.

Manx: Agh, O Yeesey vannee, nee shoh va’n chiarail ayds ayns pointeil yn Oardagh Casheric shoh? Nee son dy ghreinnaghey peccee ve dy hreishteil son pardoon fegooish lhiassaghey-bea? Nee son shoh ve dy ren oo dty uill smoo ooasle y gheayrtey, dy voddagh deiney geiyrt da pecca lesh ny smoo dy hauchys? O, cha nee!—Agh ve dy choyrt shickyrys dooin, cre cha feohdoil as ta pecca gys Jee;—cre cha neu-chooie as ta peccee son niau as maynrys;—cre cha atchimagh as ta’n stayd ocsyn, ta geddyn baase ayns nyn beccaghyn gyn arrys jeu:—V’yh dy choyrt slane shickyrys dooin jeh ny firrinyssyn shoh, as jeh’n ard imnea mooar erskyn-earroo ayds son sheelnaue cailjey, dy daink uss, O Chreest, dy ve dty oural er nyn son;—dy aa-choyrt shin ayns foayr rish nyn Yee jymmoosit,—dy choyrt kiangley orrin dy immeeaght myr sleih ta treishteil son Flaunys,—as dy chosney dooin grayse as pooar dy yannoo shen. V’yh dy choyrt orrin dy bragh dy reayl ayns cooinaghtyn dty vaase ’ys, as ooilley ny myghinyn shoh ta nyn eiyrtyssyn er;—as dy choyrt caa dooin dy choyrt stiagh fenish Jee yn ard feeuid jeh,—cour pardoon son nyn [445] beccaghyn,—as cour grayse dy lhiassaghey cooid erbee va shin er n’yannoo ass y raad.
English: [476]   But, O blessed Jesus, was this thy design in appointing this Holy Ordinance? Was it to encourage sinners to hope for pardon without amendment of life? Was it for this thou sheddest thy most precious blood, that men might sin with greater security? O, no!—But it was to convince us, how hateful sin is to God;—how unqualified sinners are for Heaven and Happiness;—how dreadful the condition of those is, who die in their sins unrepented of:—It was to convince us of these truths and of thy infinite concern for lost mankind,—that thou, O Christ, becamest a sacrifice for us;—to restore us to the favour of our offended God,—to prevail with God to accept of our repentance,—to oblige us to live like people who hope for Heaven,—and to obtain for us the grace and power to do so.—It was to make us ever mindful of these mercies, and to preserve the memory of thy death,—and to give us an opportunity of pleading the merits thereof before God,—for the pardon of our sins, and for grace to amend where we had done amiss .—

Manx: Son ny oyryn shoh v’yh, dy ren Uss, O Haualtagh, pointeil yn Sacrament Casheric shoh dy ve er ny hirveish er, as er ny ghoail liorish dy chooilley Chreestee derrey’n cheet ayds gys briwnys!
English: It was for these reasons, that Thou, O Saviour, didst ordain this Holy Sacrament to be administered and received by all Christians till thy coming again to judgment.

Manx: Nagh mooar, eisht, sheign da’n pecca ocsyn ve ta lhiggey shaghey dy hirveish, as yn pecca ocsyn ta chyndaa nyn gooyl er yn Oardagh Casheric shoh.
English: How great then must the sin of those be, who neglect to administer, and of those who turn their backs upon, this Holy Ordinance!

Manx: Foddee mayd dy jarroo jannoo myr ren Naaman, tra dooyrt yn Phadeyr rish eh dy gholl as dy niee eh-hene ayns Jordan. Foddee mee-hreishteil ’ve orrin, vod bannaghtyn whilleen as mooarey goll marish lheid yn obbyr cha playn as aashagh; as foddee mayd, trooid nyn mee-chredjue, coayl ny bannaghtyn shoh ooilley, myr va eshyn er n’yannoo, ’bey dy row coyrle share er ny choyrt da.
English: We may, indeed, do as Naaman did, when the Prophet bid him go and wash himself in Jordan. We may question whether an action so plain and easy can possibly be attended with so many and great blessings; and we may, through our infidelity, lose all those blessings, as he would have done, had he not been better advised.

Manx: Agh Creesteenyn, ta geill na graih erbee oc da nyn anmeenyn hene, cha jean adsyn dy eddrym soiaghey jeh, na chyndaa nyn gooyl er yn Oardagh Casheric shoh; er-yn-oyr, my ta toiggal oc jeh cooish erbee, sheign daue toiggal, dy vel yn saualtys oc lhie er; “as dy nee yn uill shoh dy Chreest ta glenney veih dy chooilley phecca.” [I Ean i. 7.] Nagh vod mayd treishteil son ayrn erbee ayns toilchinys Yeesey Creest, agh liorish [446] cloasal rish yn saase shoh dy ghrayse t’eh hene er n’oardaghey;—dy vel Shibber y Chiarn da Creesteenyn shen ny va’n Billey dy Vea da Adam ayns Pargeys;—as myr va eshyn, tra son e vee-viallys, va’n beaghey shen va kiarit dy yannoo eh beayn, er ny ghoail voish, myr ve fagit ayns e eer stayd dooghyssagh, ooilley-dy-lhearagh neu-abyl dy chosney yn vea veayn;—eer myrgeddin vees mainyn, mannagh vel shin goail ayrn jeh’n beaghey shoh, yn arran shoh dy vea, myr ta nyn Jiarn genmys yh:—Cha vel ny smoo dy phooar ainyn dy gholl gys niau as maynrys, na va echeysyn dy gholl stiagh reesht gys Pargeys erreish da v’er ve eebrit magh.
English: But Christians, who have any consideration and love for their own souls, will not lightly esteem, or turn their backs upon, this Holy Ordinance; because if they know any thing, they must know, that their salvation depends upon it; “and that it is this Blood of Christ which cleanseth us from all sin.” [ 1 John i. 7.] That we can hope for no share in the merits of Jesus Christ, but by closing with this means of grace which he has ordained;—that the Lord’s Supper is to Christians what the Tree of Life was to Adam in Paradise;—and that as he, when for his transgression, he was deprived of that food which was designed to make him immortal, as he was left in his pure natural condition, utterly unable to attain eternal life;—even so shall we, if we partake not of this food, this bread of life, as our Lord calls it:—We are no more capable of attaining Heaven and Happiness, than he was of returning to Paradise after he was cast out.

Manx: Ta’n resoon playn:—Fegooish grayse flaunyssagh cha vod dooinney erbee cosney stayd as condition flaunyssagh. Ta’n ghrayse shoh er ny choyrt dooin ayns bashtey, myr va’n Billey dy Vea da Adam, as t’yh dy ve er ny reayl ynrycan liorish ve biallagh da’n sarey shoh dy Yeesey Creest. Son, as eshyn, [Ean vi. 53.] “Mannagh jean shiu gee feill,” feill y Chreestiaght, “yn Mac Dooinney, as giu yn uill echey,” e uill ’sy Chreestiaght, “cha vel y vea ayndiu;” ta shen, cha vod monney agh shoh freayl seose bea flaunyssagh yn Chreestee.
English: The reason is plain:—Without a super-natural grace, no mortal man can attain to a super-natural state and condition.—This grace is given us in baptism, as the Tree of Life was to Adam, and can only be preserved by obeying this command of Jesus Christ. For, saith he, [John vi. 26.] “Except ye eat the Flesh,” the Sacramental Flesh, “of the Son of Man , and drink his Blood,” his Sacramental Blood, “ye have no life in you;” that is, nothing but this can sustain the divine life of a Christian.
Notes: The Bible reference in this paragraph is incorrect in the English but corrected in the Manx.

Manx: Ayns fockle, shoh yn ynrycan aght dy hannaghtyn ayns conaant rish Jee; ta shen, dy ve unnane jeh e lught-thie,—unnane ta fo e chiarail,—fo e choadey er-lheh;—unnane [447] ta gialdyn echey jeh, as cairys gys, reeriaght Niau, liorish bree yn Chonaant shoh.
English: In short, this is the only way to continue in covenant with God, that is, to be one of his family,—one of his care,—under his especial protection;—one who has a promise of and a right to the kingdom of Heaven, by virtue of this Covenant.

Manx: Ta’n Noo Paul [1 Cor. x.] genmys yn Sacrament shoh, ny ghoail-ayrn jeh corp Chreest; ta shen, t’yh yn Oardagh shen liorish ta sheshaght ain rish Yeesey Creest, as rish ooilley e oltyn. Liorish shoh ta shin goail-rish gys ooilley’n seihl, dy vel shin bentyn da Creest. As eisht lhig dooin cooinaghtyn, mannagh vel shin bentyn da Creest, dy vel shin bentyn da mainshter foddey smessey.
English: St. Paul [1 Cor. x.] stiles this Sacrament the Communion of the Body of Christ; that is, it is that Ordinance by which we have fellowship with Jesus Christ and with all his members;—by this we own to all the world, that we belong to Christ. And then let us remember, that if we do not belong to Christ, we do belong to a much worse master.

Manx: “Cha vod yn banglane,” as nyn Jiarn, [Ean xv. 4.] “Cha vod yn banglane mess y ymmyrkey jeh hene, mannagh vel yh tannaghtyn ayns y villey feeyney:—Chamoo “oddys shiuish, mannagh vel shiu tannaghtyn aynym's.” Nish vod nhee erbee soilshagh Creest dy ve ny s’breeoil kionfenish marin, as ve ayns unnaneys rooin, na’n Oardagh shoh; liorish ta shin jeant unnane marish Creest, as Creest marinyn?
English: [477]   “The branch,” saith our Lord, [John xv. 4.] “The branch cannot bear fruit of itself, unless it abide in the vine:—No more can ye, except ye abide in me.” Now, can any thing render Christ more effectually present with, and united to us, than this ordinance; whereby we are made one with Christ, and Christ with us?

Manx: Va’n Eayn Caisht da ny Israeliteyn shen ny ta yn Sacrament shoh da Creesteenyn. Cha row hopes erbee dy hauchys cour Israelite erbee, nagh row Fuill yn Eayn er e ghorrys, as nagh ren dy kinjagh maghey shen freayl seose cooinaghtyn jeh e livreys liorish yn oural shen. As jean Creesteenyn treishteil son myghin fegooish jannoo ny ta Creest er n’oardaghey ayns cooinaghtyn jeh yn vaase echeysyn, as son yn livreys foddey smoo ainyn?
English: The Paschal Lamb was to the Israelites what this Sacrament is to Christians. There was no hopes of security for any Israelite, who had not the Blood of the Lamb upon his door, and who did not ever after keep up the memory of his deliverance, by that sacrifice. And will Christians hope for mercy without doing what Christ has ordained in memory of his death, and our much greater deliverance?

Manx: [448]  As cooinee-jee er shoh, guee-ym erriu, myr ard-firrinys,—Ayns aght cadjin, dy jean cre-erbee ta lhiettal sleih veih goll gys y Chreestiaght, nyn lhiettal veih goll gys Niau. Lheid as ad shoh:—Lhag chiarail meerioosagh son foays nyn anmeenyn,—neu-arryltys dy ronsaghey nyn stayd spyrrydoil,—graih mooar gys y theihl as y yallooyn, as neu-arryltys dy hreigeil ad,—kiarail faase dy yannoo red ennagh traa ny traa ennagh.
English: And remember this, I beseech you, for a certain truth;—That generally speaking, whatever it is that hinders people from going to the Sacrament will hinder them from going to Heaven. Such are these:—A careless indifference for their soul’s welfare,—an unwillingness to look into their spiritual estate,—a great love for the world, and its idols, and an unwillingness to renounce them,—a faint purpose of doing it some time or other.

Manx: T’ad shoh, ro vennic ny oyryn t’ec sleih son chyndaa nyn gooyl er yn Oardagh Casheric shoh, na son cheet huggey lesh yn veggan imnea as yn veggan craueeaght shen ta soilshaghey nagh vel ennaghtyn cooie oc jeh ny bannaghtyn oddagh ad geddyn liorish.
English: These are too often the true causes of men’s turning their backs upon this Holy Ordinance, or of coming to it with an indifference and indevotion which betrays the want of a true sense of the blessings which they might receive from it.

Manx: Dy giall Jee Ooilley-niartal, dy vod adsyn ooilley ta nish kiarail dy ghoail ayrn jeh’n Sacrament Casheric shoh, geddyn leih son ooilley nyn beccaghyn ta er n’gholl shaghey,—dy vod ad ve er nyn shickyraghey ayns dy chooilley vieys,—dy vod ad ooilley ny grayseyn y gheddyn ta ymmyrchagh son y stayd t’ad ayn,—dy vod ad ve er ny lhieeney lesh giootyn y Spyrryd Noo, as goail yn Sacrament Casheric shoh myr gioal, as myr yeearlys jeh irree-seose-reesht vannee, as jeh’n vea dy bragh beayn, er graih Yeesey Creest, e vaase ta shin nish dy reayl seose cooinaghtyn jeh. Huggeysyn, &c.
English: May God Almighty grant, that all who now come to partake of this Holy Sacrament may receive the remission of all their past sins,—be confirmed in all goodness,—receive all the graces necessary for their present condition,—may be filled with the gifts of the Holy Ghost, and receive this Holy Sacrament as a pledge, as an earnest, of a blessed resurrection, and of a life eternal, for Jesus Christ’s sake, whose death we now commemorate. To whom, &c..
